Award.AwardTitle: Roles of Dissolved Methane and Sulfide in Sedimentary Dolomite Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Investigation on the roles of dissolved methane and sulfide in dolomitization
PI: Huifang Xu, University of Wisconsin ? Madison
EAR-0958000

Most hydrocarbon reservoirs in the US are related to sedimentary dolomites which are abundant in the geologic record, yet scarce in Holocene and modern marine sediments. The formation mechanism for sedimentary dolomite is still under debate. Although ankeritic dolomites have been reported in cultured media of sulfate-reducing bacteria and methanogenic groundwater, dolomite and protodolomite have not been synthesized inorganically or abiotically at room temperature. The main factor inhibiting dolomite and disordered dolomite nucleation and crystallization is the strong hydration of aqueous Mg2+ ions.
PIs hypothesize that protodolomite and disordered dolomite can nucleate and grow in solutions containing dissolved sulfide and /or organics with low molecular dipole moments. The dissolved molecules with low molecular dipole moments behave as catalysts that weaken the bonds between the water dipoles and Mg2+ therefore lowering the kinetic energy barrier of dehydration of the hydrated Mg2+. In order to test the hypothesis, PIs propose to carry out the following sets of experiments: (i) a systematic investigation on the effects of temperature and concentrations of dissolved organics and sulfide on Mg incorporation into dolomite and HMC. (ii) Study on Ca-Mg ordering kinetics in dolomite. (iii) Computer modeling of the effect of dissolved methane on surface Mg2+ dehydration using Density Function Theory (DFT) in order to understand the role of neutral species of methane in lowering the kinetic energy barrier of dolomite crystallization. All of the precipitates will be carefully characterized using X-ray diffraction, SEM, and transmission electron microscope (TEM) with associated chemical and structural analysis techniques.
Because dissolved methane and other low dielectric organics serve as catalysts for lowering the kinetic energy barrier of dehydration and dolomite crystallization, sedimentary dolomites and sandstones with dolomite cementation may be directly related to hydrocarbon source rocks or rocks influenced by hydrocarbon-bearing fluids. The proposed dolomitization mechanism may also shed new light into practical problems of hydrocarbon source rocks and reservoirs and long-term performance evaluation of sites for carbon sequestration. The proposed study will help choose appropriate sites for carbon sequestration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sedimentary dolomites are commonly used as building rocks, commercial countertops, and floor tiles. Most hydrocarbon reservoirs in the US are also related to sedimentary dolomites which are abundant in the geologic record, yet scarce in Holocene and modern marine sediments. Most sedimentary dolomites are Ca-rich and with nano-precipitates (Fig. 1).  The formation mechanism for sedimentary dolomite is still under debate. Dolomite and protodolomite have not been synthesized inorganically at room temperature. The main factor inhibiting dolomite and disordered dolomite nucleation and crystallization is the strong hydration of aqueous Mg(II) ions.

Both experimental and computer modeling results show that adsorbed hydrogen sulfide and polysaccharides can promote Mg incorporation into dolomite and anhydrous Ca-Mg-carbonates (Figs. 2-5). Low temperature dolomite precipitation and dolomitization require catalysts that can be provided by anaerobic microbes associated with carbonate sediments. Our findings may help geologists better understand catalysis in other low temperature geochemical processes.

The research results will improve understanding of global carbon cycle and interaction among paleo-climate, ocean water, microbes, and sedimentary carbonates. For instance, cap dolomite layers occur globally right after snow ball earth events. Large input of continent-derived nutrients (e.g., P) promoted growth of microorganism, and subsequent deposition of carbonates followed by dolomitization in presence of polysaccharide-rich biomass.

Our findings about catalytic roles of polysaccharides in controlling Ca-Mg-carbonate composition and mineral phases will benefit study of biomineralization of marine and non-marine organisms. Disordered Ca-Mg-carbonates are thermodynamically stable at high temperature. The findings about dissolved sulfide and polysaccharides in controlling Ca-Mg-carbonate minerals may shed light on synthesizing high temperature crystals and materials at room temperature in presence of functional catalysts.

The new findings may help to develop technology for long-term CO2 immobilization. Stable form of CO2 in nature are Ca-Mg-carbonates like calcite and dolomite. In order to form stable solid minerals, one CO2 needs one divalent cation like Ca and Mg to bind. However, Mg is can carbonate ions cannot form anhydrous phase at low temperature dues the Mg hydration problem (that is the key of dolomite problem). Our findings will help scientists to develop efficient catalysts for promoting stable anhydrous Ca-Mg-carbonates at low temperature.
